60.heading: Censorship in the Comics Industry.
60.title: "1950-1954 : la Commission de Surveillance entre Intimidation et Répression"
60.author: Thierry Crépin
60.appears_in: p. 28-27 in 9e art : Les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 4 (Jan. 1999).
notes: (49-956 ou la Démoralisation de la Jeunesse : les 50 Ans de la Loi du 16 Juillet 1949)

Begins: "Les premières années au cours desquelles a siégé la Commission de surveillance et de contrôle des publications destinées à la jeunesse présentent un intérêt particulier: elles montrent la mise en place progressive d'une stratégie d'une 'jurisprudence'. Elles coïncident aussie avec la prise de conscience, par la Commission, des limites imposées à son pouvoir."

English summary (from page 142): "1950-1954: The Supvervision Committee, Intimidation and Repression. The law of '49 created a committee for the supervision of the children's press. This committee sends reports to the Ministry of Justice which can then take various censorial measures. It also puts pressure to bear on publishers to self-censor their production. Thierry Crépin has studied the first few years of its existence and shows how it progressively defined its strategy and discovered the limits of its power."

66.heading: Censorship in the Comics Industry.
66.title: "Morris Parle de René Goscinny et de Lucky Luke"
66.author: Numa Sadoul
66.appears_in: p. 20-24 in Schtroumpf : les Cahiers de la Bande Dessinée, no. 22 (1973).
notes: Summary: Interview, in which Morris talks about collaborating with Goscinny. He compares Goscinny's writing of Lucky Luke to his own, says he hates puns and deletes them from Goscinny's scripts, but that Goscinny only puts them in to tease him. Morris says that Hergé's Tintin in the Land of the Soviets was important to him in choosing comics as his career. He speaks briefly of censorship, merchandising, animation, stage adaptation, and film adaptation of Lucky Luke. La Diligence, he says, is a parody of the film Stagecoach. Morris describes his way of depicting motion, and a gangster strip called Fred le Savant, that he did briefly with Goscinny. Includes two photographs of Morris, and a sample page of Fred le Savant.

contents.title: "C'Était le Temps où la Bande Dessinée Corrompait l'Âme Enfantine" p. 14-19

Begins: "La loi du 16 juillet 1949 réglementant les publications destinées à la jeunesse a cinquante ans.
